title: 105_hr3545
content: The "Neighborhood Integrity and Responsibility Act" may be cited as the short title. It includes a rent reasonableness test. The Housing Certificate Program under the United States Housing Act of 1937 ensures reasonable rent for assisted dwelling units by comparing them to market rates. Public housing agencies must review rents for units under consideration and lease to ensure fairness. If rent is deemed unreasonable, the agency must disapprove the lease. The agency must disapprove a lease if the rent for an assisted dwelling unit is deemed unreasonable. Rent comparisons are conducted by comparing the rent of the assisted unit with comparable unassisted units in a smaller geographical area with common characteristics. The Housing Act of 1937 is amended to require compliance with specific requirements for receiving administrative fees under the Housing Voucher Program. Compliance with rent regulations and comparisons is necessary for public housing agencies to receive fees for dwelling units. SEC. 3. LIMITATION ON ASSISTED UNITS OWNED BY SINGLE OWNER. Ownership Limitation: A public housing agency is limited to providing tenant-based assistance for a maximum of 5 dwelling units owned by any single owner, with the possibility of a waiver if the units meet housing quality standards. The ownership limitation for public housing agencies restricts assistance to 5 dwelling units per owner, with exceptions for units meeting quality standards. If an owner has more than 5 units, only the first 5 are counted towards the limit. The regulations define the term 'single owner' for purposes of the subsection, ensuring that assisted families continue to receive tenant-based assistance without interruption. The regulations define 'single owner' as any person or entity, including affiliates or subsidiaries, to be considered a single owner for the purposes of this subsection. SEC. 4. RENT PAID BY ASSISTED FAMILIES. Section 3(a)(1) of the United States Housing Act of 1937 is amended to include subparagraph (B) or (C) of section 8(c)(3). Section 8(c)(3) is also amended to allow families receiving tenant-based assistance to pay rent exceeding the determined amount under certain conditions. The United States Housing Act of 1937 is amended to allow families receiving tenant-based assistance to pay rent exceeding the determined amount under certain conditions, including for dwelling units with a maximum monthly rent equal to or exceeding 50 percent of the fair market rental for the area. The United States Housing Act of 1937 is amended to adjust the monthly assistance payment under the voucher program based on the contract rent for the unit relative to the fair market rental for the area. The United States Housing Act of 1937 is amended to adjust the monthly assistance payment under the voucher program based on the rent of the dwelling unit compared to the payment standard for the area. The assistance payment for families renting units with rent equal to or exceeding 50% of the payment standard will be the difference between the payment standard and a calculated amount based on the rent percentage. The United States Housing Act of 1937 is amended to adjust the monthly assistance payment under the voucher program based on the rent of the dwelling unit. The amendment specifies that the assistance payment will be equal to 30 percent of the rent for the unit. Additionally, there are conforming amendments made to Section 8 of the Act.
